looks good frank =3D)=A0 I can believe it took ya all week, looks complicat=
ed too(to me anyways) lol
Rhonda

--- On Sun, 6/22/08, Frank Sumption <purp=
lealiengirl@...> wrote:

From: Frank Sumption <purplealiengirl@...=
m>
Subject: [EVP-ITC] Who says there's no box advancement!?
To: "Group" <ev=
p-itc@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sunday, June 22, 2008, 12:40 AM






=A0I'm p=
retty hesitant to show this stuff, it just creates demands. 
=A0
=A0The top=
 board is linear sweep with the audio amplifiers. The bottom board is the R=
VG, and can be left off if desired.=A0A bare copper board between the two a=
cts like a shield to keep white noise out of the audio. It's designed to be=
 used with most kinds of voltage tunable radios, and this set is used with =
the Arm Band radio from RS.=A0 I still can't mass produce these, it took al=
l week to put this together, and I can hand wire a board almost as fast. Th=
en there's the problem of suitable tuners, and other parts. 
=A0
=A0There's=
 some surface mount components, adding to the assembly complexity, and diff=
iculty. 
=A0
=A0The boards are from ExpressPCB using their mini board servi=
ce, three boards=3D$60, there's no solder mask, or silkscreen, but the comp=
onents are labeled on the layout. The board=A0size is also limited, 2-1/2 X=
 3-11/16(3.8 in.).=A0
=A0
=A0I hate to stir up a hornets nest by presenting=
 new stuff, but I'm kinda proud of this. I'll share the layouts with those =
capable of assembling the boards themselves. They would still have to come =
up with tuners, controls, switches, and an enclosure, besides paying for th=
e boards to be etched. Most of the shielded wire I use is scavenged out of =
computer monitor VGA cables, old VCRs, and tape decks. You need three condu=
ctor shielded for the tone control, and two conductor shielded wire for the=
 volume controls. I do use shielded wire for the speaker outputs, mic input=
, and line outputs. Not all old VCRs have the shielded wire, and I haven't =
found anywhere to buy what is needed. 
=A0
=A0I'm calling this one 40 cuz i=
t was assembled, and made operational after #39. 
=A0
=A0Frank-S



The i=
=A2m Talkathon starts 6/24/08.=A0 For now, give amongst yourselves. Learn M=
ore

<P> I'm pretty hesitant to show this stuff, it just creates de=
mands. <BR> <BR> The top board is linear sweep with the audio amp=
lifiers. The bottom board is the RVG, and can be left off if desired. =
A bare copper board between the two acts like a shield to keep white noise =
out of the audio. It's designed to be used with most kinds of voltage tunab=
le radios, and this set is used with the Arm Band radio from RS.  I st=
ill can't mass produce these, it took all week to put this together, and I =
can hand wire a board almost as fast. Then there's the problem of suitable =
tuners, and other parts. <BR> <BR> There's some surface mount com=
ponents, adding to the assembly complexity, and difficulty. <BR> <BR>&=
nbsp;The boards are from ExpressPCB using their mini board service, three b=
oards=3D$60, there's no solder mask, or silkscreen, but the components are =
labeled on the layout. The board size is also limited, 2-1/2 X
 3-11/1=
6(3.8 in.). <BR> <BR> I hate to stir up a hornets nest by pr=
esenting new stuff, but I'm kinda proud of this. I'll share the layouts wit=
h those capable of assembling the boards themselves. They would still have =
to come up with tuners, controls, switches, and an enclosure, besides payin=
g for the boards to be etched. Most of the shielded wire I use is scavenged=
 out of computer monitor VGA cables, old VCRs, and tape decks. You need thr=
ee conductor shielded for the tone control, and two conductor shielded wire=
 for the volume controls. I do use shielded wire for the speaker outputs, m=
ic input, and line outputs. Not all old VCRs have the shielded wire, and I =
haven't found anywhere to buy what is needed. <BR> <BR> I'm calli=
ng this one 40 cuz it was assembled, and made operational after #39. <BR>&n=
